ABSTRACT
Currently two technological trends can be distinguished. On the one hand the
need to use collaborative applications or tools and on the other, the increase
in the use of mobile devices. Therefore it is of utmost importance to develop
applications distributed on mobile devices. This increases its functionality,
making it possible for several users to interact simultaneously in an application.
However, such applications must be fault tolerant. In this work
aims to identify and manage common failures in collaborative applications to
mobile devices by developing the prototype of a Framework in the
iOS4 platform.
Keywords. - - Collaborative applications, error handling, mobile devices,
Bluetooth architecture, distributed models.

ABSTRACT
Currently two technological trends can be distinguished. For
aside from the need to use collaborative applications or tools and
another, the increase in the use of mobile devices. Therefore it is from
very important to develop distributed applications on devices
mobiles. This increases its functionality, making multiple users
can interact simultaneously in an application. Nevertheless,
such applications must be fault tolerant. In this work
aims to identify and manage common application failures
collaborations for mobile devices through the development of
prototype of a Framework on the iOS4 platform.

introduction
CHAPTER I
INTRODUCTION
This chapter describes the approach to
problem found in collaborative applications
for mobile devices, in terms of their development and
problems that arise in its execution. Proposing
a solution, defining the general objectives and
specific goals that were achieved at the end of the project. By
Finally, the scope and limitations that the
system encompasses.
Page 20
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 14
TT20110007
1.1. Problematic
Technology continuously advances according to the needs that are
They present in different areas, from work to entertainment, networks
social, sports, education and mainly in videogames, where there are
a great need to communicate in an optimal and efficient way. Due to the
globalized world in which we live presents in our society the
need to move from one point to another to attend to business
labor. Thanks to advances in technology, we may be able to
work at the time of traveling by bus, plane, subway and even when walking.
This is because mobile devices are used such as: Laptops,
Netbooks, Smartphones and PDAs, among others.
Mobile devices show a substantial increase in their capabilities
both processing, storage and connectivity in the last
years [1].
The wireless technologies with which mobile devices work are
Wi-fi, bluetooth, 3G and infrared. To communicate short devices
reach, comfortably and without cables, Bluetooth technology is the most
simple. There are several classes: Class 1 devices are defined with a
range of up to 100 meters, while those of Class 2 reach from 20 to 30
meters [2].
The decrease in the costs of the aforementioned devices makes it possible to
they can be purchased more easily for most users. Therefore,
are being used more and more in various areas such as: education, science,
health, the economy and business activities, to name a few.
Due to technological development trends in both hardware and
software that flags mobile devices, it is possible to use them in
more sophisticated applications that allow you to get the most out of your
means. To add functionality, various applications have been created to
mobile devices that offer greater usefulness of resources, within
of which the collaborative applications appear.
A collaborative system or collaborative application (also known as
groupware) is a system that supports a group of people who work in
a common goal. This technology-based system (software and hardware)
provides an interface to a shared environment. Collaborative systems must
provide three essential functions to support a group of people [3]:
Page 21
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 15
•
Communication, which is the medium in which information is
shared.
•
Collaboration, helpful and service attitude towards work,
allows you to solve business problems or any activity
business.
•
Coordination, which is the action of ensuring that the team
works efficiently and together to achieve a task or
common goal.
Collaborative applications must provide the necessary means to
that users communicate and work in a synchronized way, thereby
it can be seen that communication is a fundamental aspect at the moment
to design a collaborative application [4]
The use of this technology encourages team and collaborative work both in
playful and work applications. What makes communication necessary
constant between users, to avoid transmission errors that can
cause application crashes.
These systems must have proper error handling during the
running the applications. We can cite 3 of the most common errors that
are presented in a collaborative application:
1. The situation that occurs when a node loses connection with a
collaborative application that is presented in a Synchronous context, that is,
"Face to face". Produces a need for network reconfiguration,  
which if not done properly can lead to the application
stop working properly.
2. The replication of information that is presented in the participating nodes
to the collaborative application, causes inconsistencies in shipping and
receipt of information.
3. The reconnection of a node in the collaborative application, after
a user manages to reestablish the connection with the others, causes errors
in data transactions and inconsistencies in the execution of the
app.
In addition to these three errors, errors have been detected in the applications
distributed, due to the loss of connection in the sessions between the users
who use these types of applications. On mobile devices there is no
standard for establishing collaborative connections using technology
wireless that have between a number greater than three users, despite the fact that
there are many applications that require this type of functionality.
To work with this standard it is required to have a secure connection that
is in charge of detecting and treating errors that occur in time of
execution.

IMeAC Prototype Framework

TT20110007
1.2. Proposed solution
Due to the problems in the connectivity of collaborative applications between
mobile devices that we discussed in the previous section are required
handle errors in a collaborative scheme using a Framework
prototype that allows mobile device programmers to have the
tools needed to efficiently handle errors that
could arise in collaborative applications in an architecture
bluetooth, since it adapts to the needs of the transmission of
information thanks to its transfer speed and above all to the ease
presented in the configuration of devices on the network compared to other
similar technologies.
The scope that this architecture can present depends on the
device classification, being only a power reference
transmission, so that devices of a class are compatible with the
other. In order to have application connectivity in our project
collaborative face-to-face, we use devices with class 2 devices
bluetooth that adapt to these coverage needs.
The Framework proposed in this project helps to handle errors in
connectivity using Bluetooth-based communication technology with
in order to promote better stability in the applications used,
due to the fact that the most common errors that can present said
architecture.
1.3. General objective
Develop the Prototype of a Framework for a middleware that allows the
creation of synchronous collaborative applications with an architecture oriented
error handling using a device-based Bluetooth connection
Apple mobiles.

collaborative applications.
•
Implement mechanisms for the reconfiguration of
users.
•

•
Generate a library for handling errors associated with a
middleware.
•
Develop test applications that help validate the
handling of the errors that the prototype contemplates.

1.5. Justification
There is currently a great need for immediate information on hand
anywhere we are; to contribute to this technology
mobile has increased its capacities for both memory and services
multiple available [5]. This allows the possibility of using them in
more sophisticated applications that can make better use of your
capabilities for a better service and thus be able to use them in any area
where it is needed; therefore mobile devices have had a great
global acceptance [6]. It is important to mention that the use of this
technology encourages teamwork and collaboration both in applications
playful as well as work; being necessary a constant communication between
users, to avoid transmission errors that cause failures in the
applications, such as the loss of connection of some user in the
application, as well as its subsequent connection or the replication of the information of
nodes when several users are connected simultaneously, since
that can be caused by various causes, including leaving the area of
coverage of architecture, environmental or equipment failures [7].
There may be problems in the execution of the applications
collaborative due to the presence of critical situations where they have
user participation. Solving the errors that can be generated in the
collaborative application communication using mobile devices,
promotes better management of these applications since there is no
similar prototype that deals with such errors.
This project aims to benefit programmers who develop
collaborative applications, so that they have greater support for users,
with proper error handling and therefore better execution
of applications, this allows to improve communication between devices
running the same collaborative application.
Therefore, it is also intended to benefit users who require such
applications since applications are also developed that validate the use of the
Framework thus facilitating the construction of other subsequent applications.
Said selected applications will be a "Pacman" game and a "Chat",
because this type of program mostly requires the intervention
of several users for its proper execution; which uses our
Error handling framework for connecting devices and the
treatment of errors that occur in the application. What will prevent
the execution of the game is interrupted abruptly by some error in the
communication between devices.

2.2 Theoretical Framework
2.2.1.
Mobile devices
2.2.1.1.
Concept
Mobile devices can be defined differently when looking at
from different perspectives. These can be defined in terms of the
services that offer or are based on the level of functionality related to the
devices. However, for the development of this terminal work
we will use the following:
A mobile device refers to a computing device whose size is
smaller than a laptop, they usually have a small screen, a small
keyboard with miniature buttons or a touch screen with the stylus of the
entry [10].
2.2.1.2.
Actual state
Mobile devices play an important role in modern society.
They are used by people of all social classes for different purposes.
They can be found in the fields of education, entertainment, medicine,
communication services, military systems, and so on.
Current mobile computing devices, such as pocket computers,
personal digital assistants (PAD), and mobile phones have a great
Market. Currently there are approximately 4 billion mobile phones
[eleven].
2.2.2.
Mobile Operating Systems
Operating systems are the programs that allow many
machines. On mobile phones they are increasingly important. They convert to
phone into a complete multimedia device becoming devices
intelligent thanks to the incorporation of operating systems more and more
powerful and with greater possibilities. From the first devices with
Symbian, even the desired iPhone, mobiles have also included other
systems like Palm, Linux or Windows Mobile, looking for a standardization.
Aware of the possibilities of adding all kinds of services in the systems
mobile phones, the latest to join this race are Google and Yahoo, with
new platforms that promise to break the barrier between
desktop and mobile services [12].

Android
Android consists of a Linux-based kernel, with middleware, libraries, and
APIs written in C and software applications running on a framework of
applications that includes a series of libraries compatible with Java based on
Apache Harmony. Android uses a virtual machine called Dalvik with a
Java build named just in time. [13]
2.2.2.2.
ios
iOS (formerly called iPhone OS) is a mobile operating system for
Apple originally developed for the iPhone, later being used in others
later created mobile devices iPad and iPod Touch. It is a derivative
Mac OS X, which in turn is based on Darwin BSD. The iOS has 4 layers of
abstraction: the kernel layer of the operating system, the layer of "Services  
Main ", the layer of" Media "among which is the  
Bluetooth and Wi-fi sensors and the “Cocoa Touch” layer. The whole system is  
located on the device's “/ root” partition, it occupies less than 500 megabytes.  
[14]

Symbian is the smartphone platform of choice built by

decreased and contributors continue to optimize the software. Symbian is
now able to run on low-cost devices. This allows Nokia
and others to produce a large number of Symbian-powered devices for markets in
concise cost, whether or not demanding users. [fifteen]

2.2.4.2.
Characteristics
•
Resource sharing. Applications can use resources
located in any computer system.
•
Reliability. A distributed system provides the availability, it is
that is, the continuity of services despite failures. This is achieved
through redundancies in the network and resources, as well as in the
OS services.
•
Computing acceleration. Computing acceleration is
achieved by running parts of a computation in parallel in
different computer systems.
•
Communication. Users of its subcomputations located in
different nodes can communicate reliably using the
OS services.
•
Incremental growth. Open system standards
allow new subsystems to be added to a distributed system without
having to replace or upgrade existing subsystems. In this way,
the cost to increase the capabilities of a distributed system is
proportional to the desired additional capacity.
2.2.4.3.
Advantages and disadvantages
Advantage:
• Reduction of the cost of the computer and access to the network
• Resource sharing
• Scalability
• Fault tolerance
Disadvantages:
• Multiple points of failure
• Security

2.2.5.
Framework
2.2.5.1.
Definition
A Framework is a set of classes that incorporates an abstract design of
solutions for a family of related problems; in other words, a
Framework consists of a set of classes (not necessarily abstract),
whose instances collaborate (fit) in a certain application, it is
intended to be expanded, i.e. reused (abstract design), and has a
domain-specific [22].
2.2.5.2.
Characteristics
•
Extensibility: Have the ability to inherit functionality to
the applications or the possibility of customizing parts of it
but keeping the original design.
•
Easy Understanding: Understandable from the point of view of the
programmer.
•
Inversion of control; that is, the Framework controls the
application and not vice versa.
•
Modularity, by encapsulating volatile data
behind the implementation of stable interfaces.
•
It should have additional information that tells the user that
must be completed or extended from the Framework.
•
Facilitates software rejection.
•
Have restrictions to ensure its integrity.
•
It is from a specific domain [23,24].
2.2.5.3.
Documentation
Johnson proposes three types of documents that are necessary for a
Framework:
• The purpose of the Framework. A description of the domain of the
Framework, the requirements it intends to meet, and the limitations that
have.
• The use of the Framework. A description of how the
Framework will be used.
• The design of the Framework. A description of the structure and
Framework behavior.
Page 35
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 29
2.2.5.4.
Components of a Framework
Hook methods
Hook methods explicitly divide the layout of the structure into
interfaces and behavior along with the variable parts to be
customized by the application.
Hook methods will also help ensure that changes or
Extensions are seamlessly integrated into the design and implementation of the Framework.
There are two types of Hook methods, the first of which is to satisfy the
requirements, while the others to provide adaptation to the Framework.
Components (Objects).
Frameworks must provide a context of reusable components.
Each component makes assumptions about its environment. [25]
Dispatcher
It is in charge of handling the Framework events. When they occur
events, it reacts by invoking appropriate methods on control objects
pre-registered, which perform the processing of specific tasks on the
facts.
Classification
There are two types of general classifications for a Framework, one is
determined by its extensibility technique that can be seen in Table 4 ,
while the other takes into account his Domain as can be seen in the
Table 5 [24].

2.2.5.5.
Development process
The development of a Framework focuses on 3 main activities:
• Analysis of the domain problem. It is a broad analysis that deals with
obtain the requirements for the problem domain, along with the
future needs.
• Framework design. It consists of identifying the abstractions
correctness of the requirements as well as identifying the variable parts and
stable of the future Framework.
• Framework instantiation. This depends on the type of Framework [22].

say, communication.
But well, specifically a Middleware is a reusable software that is
between applications and the underlying operating system, stacks of
hardware and network protocols.

2.2.7.
Collaborative Applications.
Collaborative applications, also called groupware are applications of
computing that allow users to work and share information with each other
[27].
The term Groupware has been defined as “a system based on  
computers that support groups of people involved in tasks (or
goals) common and that provides an interface to a shared environment ”. The  
requirements that are more specifically associated with groupware systems
are fundamentally related to the main characteristics that
these systems exhibit: communication, collaboration and coordination [28].
Today, collaborative applications, in addition to providing the
adequate infrastructure to support group work, must support the
dynamic nature of the group at runtime. Because of this, it is
groupware applications are required to provide mechanisms that
make it possible to change the way in which group work is organized, as well as
give support to different work styles of the organization [29].
Page 38
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 32
TT20110007
There are many classifications for groupware, perhaps the best known is the
scheme that focuses on the time and place of the interaction as you can
observe in Figure 1. Therefore we can analyze the collaboration along
of two dimensions of time and space, where the cooperation of the parties
You may not be in the same place and time when it comes to collaborating.
Figure 1. Types of Collaborative Systems
For the purposes of this project we will rely on when users are
meet at the same time / place ( synchronous ) [28]: This is the
traditional face-to-face communication, marked by encounters,
presentations and discussions that you work on at the same time. Several
techniques and technologies help facilitate these activities such as rain
ideas, whiteboards, electronic meeting systems,
conferences with audio and video, among others; but all are based on the
immediate proximity of the participants.
The design of a groupware application must consider the aspects that are
explained below [30]:
•
An adequate presentation of the contributions of the
individuals in the application, both for him and for other users.
The contribution of each of the users in the application must be
recognized in some way by him and others who are
participating, according to the rules established in said application,
seeking not to affect the integrity of the user or group.
Page 39
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 33
•
Recognition of the location of the individual and the group. The
The user must know at all times, where they are located (within
the application) both him and the other participants so as not to get lost in
the context of the application.
•
Include restrictions or special privileges in the use of channels
for social interaction. The user must be able to express his
intention to get involved within the application in order to avoid annoyances
due to unexpected participation requirements.
•
Construction of social roles similar to those formed in the
organizations. This interpretation of the role should be followed by
corresponding functions or responsibilities within the application.
An example of this interpretation is shown when leading a meeting.
•
Recognition of activity within the system. The user
must be aware of what activities are being carried out within
the application, who carries them out and which ones are involved.
•
Identification with the working group. It is necessary to carry a
record of all the activities carried out by the groups in order to
monitor and evaluate progress and achievements.
Collaboration and other types of group work are used to bring people together
for different reasons, among which the following stand out: socializing, working together,
cooperate and contribute to the production of something or to innovate. Different objectives
can be achieved by applying collaborative techniques [28],
such as: communications, the exchange of information, the construction of
a community, knowledge management, the joint contribution of a
work product.
Collaborative applications, in addition to providing the infrastructure
suitable to withstand group work, they must withstand nature
group dynamics at runtime, with mechanisms that allow
change the way work is organized.
In general, collaborative applications that feature a
session, do not separate the mechanisms that establish the shared space from the
session management policy. This separation is important, since it allows giving
support changes in group work in a more appropriate and flexible way.
This is for two main reasons. On the one hand, the way in which
connection is established, sessions are started or stopped, and on the other hand,
have designed session management policies that allow structuring the
the way in which group work is organized, as well as the way in which
they can carry out. In this way, a change in the organizational structure
of the group would affect the session handling policy, but not the session handler.
session.
Page 40
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 34
TT20110007
Collaborative applications are typically large-scale systems that
require solutions according to the behavior of the system, that is,
self-adapting and dynamic solutions. Session handling policies are
a feasible solution for the management of groupware applications, since they allow
specify dynamically adaptable strategies, which can be easily
modified without changing the code or stopping the system execution; which
have errors that require handling with characteristics similar to that of the
adaptive software.
Adaptive software is based on the need to adjust or transform the
system functionality according to the new requirements that appear
(changes in the environment, new user needs, different
devices, etc.) without affecting the operation of the system.
Regarding the investigation of adaptive systems centered on the group, the
Existing systems try to adjust the shared workspace, taking
take into account the changes that occur in the system. For this reason, it is necessary
provide mechanisms to detect such changes. Once it has
a change has been detected, a blanket agreement is often necessary to determine
if the adaptation process can be carried out.
At that point, the system must decide which components are involved
in the corresponding adaptation process. This process should be done
coordinated manner, so that the overall functionality of the
system and all its components while the fitting is in progress.
With regard to adaptive collaborative systems, they are considered
various dimensions, such as [29]:
• Access control
• Concurrency control
• Docking views
• Extensible architectures
• Mobility support
Regarding existing collaborative applications on the market, we can
highlight those that are presented later, where it allows the
users send data to each other, even though application users do not
they can tell that they are collaborating. This definition equates
essentially communication with collaboration:
Some of the traditional applications that qualify as the applications of
collaboration according to this definition [31]:
•
An email application - linking occurs
when a user starts it sends a message to one or more collaborators.
•
A talking program - bonding can affect each
keystroke or ENTER key when hit.

IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 35
•
A database application - linking occurs
when a user retrieves the data that was deposited by another
user or when a user is blocked by another user has
acquired the lock that the first one needs.
•
A whiteboard application allows users to create a drawing
common - join occurs when the drawing action performed by a
user communicates to other users.
•
A video conferencing application - linking occurs
when a user's voice or video is transmitted to other users.

need for different developers and users of different devices
Apple phones, in using a framework for application development
collaborative, in these devices that allow the programmer to build their
applications without having to delve deeply into the connection between
equipment, as well as handling errors that may arise during the
Connection. However to date no standard has been proposed as such,
which leads directly to an initial acceptance of the development of the system
proposed in this project, which in a simple way covers said
requirements and expectations, to provide the information concerning the
collaborative application development in a timely and reliable manner.
Based on interviews and questions asked in various discussion forums
held with collaborative application developers, it was corroborated that
do not present any opposition to the development of the project, so the system
it is operationally feasible.
As there is no system similar to the framework to be built, there is no
properly an impediment or difficulty of the various developers in
work in conjunction with current tools, our system represents
a complement to the current tools offered by the Apple company and
This will allow the various programmers to benefit in cost and time.
of collaborative applications.

easy handling and understanding for both end users and developers
Apple, along with all the documentation and support necessary to achieve a
importance in the development of collaborative applications on devices
mobiles.

3.2. Framework requirements
3.2.1 Functional Requirements
1.- The system must provide the user with a fully configurable medium
that allows you to make and choose how to make connections between devices
mobile phones allowing you to use our tools to create
of distributed networks or use those provided by the Apple company.
1.1 The user will choose the maximum number of elements, and / or minimum or fair that
you can connect to the network or decide to have the end user do it.
1.2 The user will choose the technology they want to use to develop their
application, either via Bluetooth or Wi-fi.
1.2.1 If the option chosen is Bluetooth, you can choose between using the
IMeAC framework or the standard provided by the Apple company (Gamekit)
to develop your application.
1.2.2 When the chosen option is Wi-fi, the user will work directly with the
standard provided by Apple company (CFNetwork).
1.3 The user can decide what kind of errors the framework can handle by
him or in his case work them himself.
1.4 The user can choose the priority in terms of speed of shipment and
receiving messages.
2.- The system will develop an ad-hoc mobile network distributed for the
communication of various mobile devices based on the configuration of the
Username.
2.1 The network between mobile devices will be developed with the iMeaC framework,
only in the event that the number of participants is equal to or greater than 3,
otherwise it will be handled by the framework developed by Apple.
2.2 The system will have a table containing the information of all the
nodes of the network to develop the necessary connections according to the
algorithm to use.
3.- During the connection of mobile devices, the system must verify if the
network is still intact, otherwise you need to provide the necessary methods
so that the application continues to work in the same way or very similar to how
it was before having undergone the change.
3.1 The system must allow you through the use of shipping and receiving methods
of messages making use of a generic object that allows informing the
devices the content of the message, as well as the source in terms of time,
place and manner.
Page 54
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 48
TT20110007
3.2 The system will perform a monitoring based on the user configuration
of certain types of errors and deal with them in the best possible way.
3.2.2 Non-Functional Requirements
Reliability
1. The system must be reliable for the user, since the user will never change its
functionality as far as connectivity is concerned, due in the way of what
possible to maintain the application with the least amount of modifications that
must be performed.
2. The iMeAC Framework guarantees its functionality 100% as long as the
tool used by the intermediate user to develop applications
collaborative is Xcode 3.2 or later, which has the SDK integrated for
development on iPhone version 3.0 or later.
User interface
3. The system will provide depending on the settings made by the user
intermediate, a simple user interface for connectivity between
mobile devices.
4. In the event that the treatment of an error requires a message and / or
additional control to the end user, it must be concise and easy to use so that
these users can make a decision and thus have a continuity of the
app.
Efficiency
5. The user interface should not occupy more resources than those allowed by the
mobile device, as this will have an impact on processing time and on
all in the functionality of the iMeAC Framework, being ineffective to the end user.
Compatibility
6. The system will only work on Apple mobile devices as of its
third generation or later of touch devices, otherwise,
it will alert the downstream user that it is an unsupported device.
7.The system will work on devices that have the operating system
iOS 4.0 or later, otherwise, it will alert the downstream user
that it is an unsupported device.

4.1. Development Methodology
As we know, the choice of methodology is a crucial part for the
software development, therefore in order to define the most optimal methodology
to develop this project; that is, the prototype Framework for
handling errors in collaborative applications, we need to have as
reference all that we can handle for your development as shown in
the Table 17 .
METHODOLOGY
FEATURES
RUP
The Unified Process uses the Unified Modeling Language
(UML) in the preparation of all the drawings of the system is
directed by use cases (use-case driven), focused on the
architecture (architecture-centric), iterative and incremental.
The unified process has two dimensions:
A horizontal axis that represents time and shows the
aspects of the process life cycle.
A vertical axis that represents the disciplines, which group
activities in a logical way.
The Unified Process is component-based
XP
Methodology for agile software development.
Programming based on customer wishes.
The team is made up of project managers, developers and
the client.
Maximize group work.
XP defines four variables for software projects: cost,
time, quality and scope.
It is adapted to change, its four phases are Analysis, Design,
Implementation and testing, iteratively.
A.M
It is a practice-based methodology for modeling
cash from software systems.
It is a collection of practices, guided by principles and values
that can be applied by software professionals.
Principles: Assume simplicity., Incremental change, Model
with a purpose, Multiple models, Quick Feedback.
SCRUM
Scrum is an agile project development methodology.
AUP
Promotes iterations in development throughout the entire cycle
life of the project.
Software developed in a unit of time is called
an iteration, which should last from one to four weeks.
Each iteration of the life cycle includes: planning, analysis of
requirements, design, coding, review and documentation.
An iteration should not add too much functionality to
justify the launch of the product to the market.

Page 58

4.2.1.2
Logical Architecture of the Framework
Figure 3. Logical architecture of the iMeAC prototype Framework
Page 59
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 53
Frequently, a diagram is used to illustrate the different layers that
separate the application at the highest level from the lowest which is the hardware, such as
can be seen in Figure 3 .
The kernel provides low-level communication such as device drivers,
which handle running program management, memory management
and input-output operations.
The layer called Core Services provides low-level operations
such as support for collections, networks, file management, thread, time and
battery management.
The Application Services include support for graphic processing such as
it is OpenGL and Quicktime.
The Cocoa Touch layer includes the Foundation and UIKit Frameworks
respectively. Foundation offers classes for working with arrays, strings,
memory management and file system. The UIKit framework provides classes
to handle views, windows, documents, user interfaces visually
nice that Apple phones are known for [8] and the GameKit that is
of our particular interest which is the means of communication between devices
mobile phones via Bluetooth.
Next to this layer is our iMeaC framework which will interact
directly with the Gamekit and all kinds of Cocoa Touch that the
developer requires to make your application.
Finally, there is the Application layer that will be the one that interacts with
graphic and tactile form with the end user who will be in charge of using
said application.

4.3.3 Class Diagram
The next section deals with the design of the class diagram, about the
IMeAC prototype framework for error handling, based on the
use case diagrams together with the activity diagrams, were defined
for this project a total of 10 classes plus the Delegate who will serve
to implement our Framework shown in Figure 39 .
In Figure 40 the complete class diagram is described with all
functions of each of them. A brief explanation of the functionality of
Each class that integrates our Framework is the following:
Dispatcher : This will work as the main class of our Framework,
will be in charge of managing the events that occur within it, since
As can be seen in the diagram, it will contain all the classes of the
Framework by composition.
Users table : In this class you will have the basic management of all users
that will contain the network within a specific collaborative application.
User ViewController : It is a controller integrated to the user table, which
provides us with lifetime aspects for the Management of users such as their
ID or MAC address.
Wi-fi manager : It is the class in charge of the communication of the devices
with the auxiliary server; that is, it will be in charge of transmitting to said auxiliary the
report when a connection or failure occurs as the case may be.
<<Interface>> iMeAC Delegate : It is a protocol in charge of communication
between the application and the Framework, in order to implement the
connectivity and error handling.

information as shown in Figure 51 , where you must first of all
make connections between devices using bluetooth architecture
making use of a table of users that contains essential information for the
development of the application within what is contemplated: An identifier, the
name of the devices, their status and a generic object.

each other, sending and receiving messages that will be reflected in the execution of
the collaborative application.
Network monitoring is accessed so we can observe what is happening
in the bluetooth network of our application, so you can see if even
the connections between the nodes are still active or if any of the
errors contemplated in the Framework, and in turn classify it for later
execute the corresponding treatment.
You can access the error of the disconnection of a Node, error of the replication of
information or error of the reconnection of a node when detected by the
monitoring the network and immediately being able to correctly handle each of
independently so that later the Connection Manager can be
modify as required and therefore the Users Table has the
updated information of the nodes that make up the network, making the
collaborative application can continue its execution properly.

5.1.2.6
Treatment of Node Reconnection Error
As shown in Figure 58 corresponding to the Block Diagram of the

should try.

are currently in it, saving the modifications in the Table of

collaborative application.

its execution.

a few moments there is a replication of the node information and after a
between 5 and 20 seconds the corresponding field of the UIPickerView is eliminated
to the Bluetooth identifier (PeerID) that is no longer available for the
creation of the network shown in Figure 126 , thus avoiding wanting to
connect to an address that is no longer available to create a connection
with it and that this causes an error in the connections between the devices of the
net. It should be noted that in this case it may also happen that the
UIPickerView object almost imperceptibly to the user, since they can
coincide the times in which the device is deleted and appears again to
the connection and for this reason the user would not detect that it has been deleted and
detect by going to the UIPickerVIew. With which we conclude that despite the
various behaviors that can be generated due to manipulation
of mobile devices, the Framework can handle the error of the replication of the
information correctly, because it removes the name and consequently the
identifier that the device may have had previously, thus avoiding
that you want to generate a connection with a PeerID that is not available and
consequence generates a greater error in the collaborative application locally and
on the other devices that are connected to your network.

6.3.2 Collaborative Application "eDraw"
In order to check the functionality of the iMeAC Framework for creating
collaborative applications eDraw application was developed. In this application the
users who participate in its execution, can make drawings on a canvas that
on each device corresponds to its touch screen, in turn within it
canvas you can observe the actions that other users perform as shown
shown in Figure 154. In the development of this application it was possible to verify
how by making use of the iMeAC Framework it was possible to configure in a more
fast connection between participating devices within the application,
besides having a handling of errors that could appear in the network.
Figure 154. Example of how the eDraw application works
When the eDraw application starts running there are two buttons on
the screen, as shown in Figure 155. To start correctly with the
execution, you must first click on the "Connections" button, through which you  
performs a controller change and the screen corresponding to the
IMeAC Framework shown in Figure 156. This screen contains how
elements in the UIPickerView where the nodes that are
available to make a connection with the "Connect" button.
Figure 155. eDraw Application Initial Driver
Page 174
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 168
TT20110007
Figure 156. Controller for making connections between devices
At the bottom there is the "Users Table" button, which allows you to view the  
list of devices that have connected to the network to be able to use the
collaborative application as shown in Figure 157 , to return to the
Framework controller, click on the "Return" button located in the part  
upper left. Once in the mentioned controller you will find the button
"Exit" at the bottom, which makes the necessary controller change to
return to the initial screen of the application.
Figure 157. Table of Users of the devices connected to the network
Once the corresponding connections have been made between the control devices,
the network can be started to draw on the canvas by clicking the "Start" button,  
later the blank screen is observed and with two buttons on the
bottom labeled “Options” and “Clean” as shown in   Figure 158 . The
first open the configuration panel visible in Figure 159 which provides the
functionality of being able to change the width of the lines that are drawn and the color that
is chosen to draw, with the possibility of making combinations with the colors: red,
green and blue, to generate the desired color which is displayed on the panel
lower.
Page 175
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 169
Figure 158. Drawing canvas of the eDraw application
Figure 159. Configuration Panel for drawing in eDraw
Once the parameters with which to work have been selected, click on the
"Done" button located on the upper left and you will return to the controller of the  
application that acts as a canvas. The second button on this controller has the
function of cleaning the entire canvas, erasing the information that has been stored in
he. Once you have started to draw, in a certain period of time the
drawing that is being made locally is sent to the other devices that
are connected within the same network, so that they can be shared
the progress made by each participant of the collaborative application.

CONCLUSIONS
The results we obtained are described below
after developing the iMeAC Framework prototype and
some proposals to be able to increase its functionality,
in order to provide greater services to
developers using the Framework.

7.1 RESULTS
• Analysis of the development of a Framework for handling errors in
collaborative applications.
• Include the possibility of configuring the prototype of the Framework, depending on
of programmer needs.
• Make the connection between mobile devices of the Apple brand with a
number greater than three nodes.
• Appreciation of the appearance of errors in the execution of the applications
collaborative.
• Handling the error of the disconnection of a node.
• Treatment of the replication error of a node.
• Analysis and management of the behavior of the closing functions of
app
• Treatment of a node reconnection error.
• Monitoring the collaborative application network.
• Creation of the Users Table.
• Optimization of algorithms for connecting, sending and receiving data
between devices.
• Development of the test application "eChat"
• Development of the test application "eDraw"
• Development of the test application "ePacman"
• Development and implementation of a prototype Framework for managing
some bugs in collaborative applications.

7.2 DISCUSSION
• It was required to analyze the way in which the prototype of a
Framework to carry out the information transaction between the users that
it is needed for the realization of the collaborative application and the treatment
of common errors in its execution.
• Depending on the characteristics of each collaborative application, the
developer must have the possibility to adapt the Framework to
have greater flexibility in application programming.
• It must be possible to make the connection with more than three nodes without
present problems in their connectivity, in order to improve performance
that is presented when using other Frameworks.
• When executing the collaborative applications, various errors are presented in
its execution, among which the most recurrent are:
disconnection of a node, the failure of the replication of information of a node
and the error corresponding to reconnecting a node
• When a node disconnection error occurs, you have to
verify the stability of the collaborative application in terms of delivery and
reception of information between nodes that are part of the same network.
• When a node leaves the game in a collaborative application and returns
to enter it, the information replication error is presented, due to
to the bluetooth identifier that is provided at each start of the
service changes.
• The way in which an application exits its execution must be analyzed.
either by decision of the user or the mobile device system,
depending on the situation that arises, observing which ones occur
with more frenquency.
• When a node wants to reconnect with the others
participants that are in the network must carry out the
relevant connections and verify that the network organization is
restructure so that it continues to function properly.
• In order to have control over what is happening on the network at all times,
must have constant monitoring, analyzing the connections between the
nodes and their data transactions.

TT20110007
• To have knowledge of the users who connect to the network, it is
It is important to have a record of the most representative data of each one
of the nodes that are participating in the application through a table of
users.
• When the connections between the devices are made and it begins to exist
exchange of information between them, it is observed that if this interaction is
slow, then you will not have an effective response from the application
collaborative.
• The eChat test application was developed to support the effectiveness of the

7.3 CONCLUSIONS
It has been possible to design and implement the prototype of a Framework that facilitates the
communication between Apple brand mobile devices, as well as shipping and
reception of data between them and the treatment of various common errors that are
present in the execution of collaborative applications.
This Framework can be configured depending on the requirements that
need the collaborative application and the needs detected by the
developer, thus facilitating the development of this type of applications and leaving
that the developer focuses on the logic of the application, allowing to develop
more complex programs in a short time, saving effort and
means.
The development of the connectivity of the
devices using bluetooth technology for a number greater than 3 nodes in
the same network, because when using other Frameworks provided by Apple
There were drawbacks causing problems and instability in the
connecting the nodes, causing the collaborative application to fail.
We can see that when an application is running
collaborative, there may be various errors that can cause failures in
the execution of it, causing data to be sent, received and manipulated
erroneous or defeated; therefore errors occur in the connectivity of the
connected devices which can trigger a partial and complete failure of the
the collaborative application. So we investigate through tests, trials and
information gathering, which of the errors mentioned above were
the most recurrent and with the greatest impact on the stability of applications
collaborative; within which are the following:
disconnection of a node, the failure of the replication of information of a node and the
error corresponding to reconnecting a node.
In what corresponds to the error of disconnection of a node in the network, the
problem that when trying to send notifications to a node that is no longer in
the network causes inconsistency in the data to be sent and also delays the sending of data
to other devices that continue on the network causing instability in the
application, so it was necessary to restructure the network of the running application
so that only the data will be sent to the devices that will continue to be connected,
in addition to notifying them by means of messages that a node had
abandoned the network, in order that users were aware that it has been
disconnected a node and if necessary change the way in which they were
using the app.
Page 200
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 194
TT20110007
The other type of error for which a treatment was carried out was the error of the
replication of information, in which we realize that having abandoned a
node the game and re-enter it the replication of information was presented
of the node because the bluetooth identifier that is provided in each
service startup changes, causing applications not to detect that it is
treats the same device and consequently cannot correctly perform the
execution of the application, we realized that various
cases of this type of error depending on the time it takes the user of the
device to return to the application, because if the time it takes to return to the
The application is very short, you can still observe for a period of time the
information replication, however the node that no longer exists is deleted
physically as a possibility to make a connection and prevent it from being
try to connect to a nonexistent node causing data inconsistency
of the application.
One of the problems that arose in the development of the Framework was
that when you exit an application that is running in a
Apple brand mobile device changes the execution of internal functions of
this, depending on the way in which the application was exited since it varies if
It is the case that it is only minimized or if it is completely removed
her; either because the user needs it or because the device system
requires the application to be minimized due to receiving a call on the
iphone or the device is turned off directly, so throughout the
development of the framework prototype we had to contemplate all possible
scenarios that could arise and thus be able to deal with the errors that
more frequently they arise in collaborative applications, due to the various
reasons that occur in a mobile device of the Apple brand.
We also realized that error handling was required at the time that
a node wished to reconnect to the network, which could be at the time when
connections were being made, in this case it had to be included again
as a possible node to connect with the other devices or also
when there had already been a previous connection, in which case this node must have
be able to visualize the other nodes involved in the collaborative application and
connect with one of them to be able to obtain the current data in which
found the application and thus be able to be included in its execution.
One of the aspects that we realized was needed to detect the
errors in collaborative applications at the right time was that they were
was constantly monitoring the network created for the
operation of these applications, in order to keep track of the actions
that happen in the application and to be able to give an effective solution to the types of errors
contemplated in the Framework, so that these are solved as much as possible
quickly possible during the time of its execution.
Page 201
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 195
In addition to this, we observed that a User Table was required to be included
in which the most representative data of each of the nodes will be recorded
who were participating in the network, so that they could have control of each
one of them and you could quickly and easily know its status in the
different times of the collaborative application.
Another factor that was analyzed for the development of the prototype of the Framework
was the optimization of the detection of the various devices that can be
connect in the network, in order that the developer would not have problems in
scheduling connectivity for devices and end users does not
they will wait an excessive time for the beginning of the execution of the applications
collaboratives that have the prototype of the Framework included. In the same way
debugged, simplified the reception and sending of messages through the network with which the
developer will not need to use too many lines of code to
perform these actions, in addition to the end users of the applications
can enjoy efficient shipping and receiving; but above all effective of the
data between the devices that are using the application and may have a
better execution of them.
Having developed the prototype of the iMeAC Framework, we developed the application
test "eChat", in which it is included and helped us to verify that  
This Framework provides the necessary functions both for the connection between the
devices, such as the detection and treatment of the three errors that are
they gazed at him.
When developing the eDraw application we were able to verify that the prototype of the
IMeAC Framework is a valuable tool for developers of
collaborative applications, reducing development time for connectivity
between devices with the possibility of dealing with errors that occur in the
execution of the application such as the reconnection of the participants
suspend the session of the game and want to re-enter the network
subsequently.
The test application “ePacman” was also developed, where in addition to  
use the Framework for the connection of the different devices and the treatment
of errors that could occur in its execution, it was made of the tools
to restrict the number of users, as well as the sending of corresponding data
to the status of each player, which requires an efficient sending of information, since
in a collaborative application it is necessary to have access to the data of the
other devices in real time.

IMeAC Prototype Framework

After having carried out the different tests on the operation of the
prototype of the Framework in the collaborative applications that we develop with
this goal; We conclude that it is feasible to develop a Framework for the
development of collaborative applications, transparently managing the
connections between nodes that make up the network used for operation
of collaborative applications, as well as error handling
recurring events that occur in the execution of these applications.
7.4 FUTURE WORK
A possible improvement to the system is to integrate the Framework prototype
Wi-Fi technology, so that Ad-Hoc type connections can be made,
allowing collaborative applications to be handled in scenarios that do not
have the appropriate infrastructure and include the most recurring errors
in collaborative applications with this type of technology because there are
some variations with the bluetooth architecture for its sending protocols and
reception of data over a network, as well as the range and bandwidth that
they drive.
Another point of improvement is the adaptation of the iMeAC Framework prototype
for the development of collaborative applications in Web environments, which will help
facilitate the programming of connections between the different users that
participate in them, facilitating the treatment of errors that arise in their
execution, as these are similar to the ones shown in the apps
studied.
An improvement to the prototype of the Framework is to make the functions compatible
for the Android mobile device platform, because it has had a great
acceptance in society, therefore a large number of
applications for that mobile operating system and the devices that include it
have the necessary hardware resources to implement the functions
that contains the iMeAC Framework prototype, making it easier to develop
collaborative applications for said platform.

Annex A.
Protocols and Delegates in Cocoa
A protocol is a list of methods that is shared between classes. Methods
listed in the protocol do not necessarily have to be implemented, their goal is to
have some other class implement them. A protocol provides a way to define a
set of methods that are related to a specific name. Methods
are commonly documented so you know what they need to develop and so on
this way you can implement them in your own class definitions.
If you decide to implement all the methods required for a protocol in
In particular, your class is said to conform or adopt that protocol.
Defining a protocol is very easy. Just use the @protocol directive
followed by the name of the protocol. After that, the methods are declared as
it is done in the interface section. All method declarations terminate
with the @end directive, which is part of the protocol.
If you choose to work with the Foundation framework, you may find that it contains
various pre-defined protocols. One of them is NSCopying, which
declare a method that you need to implement in your class to support the copy
of objects with the copyWithZone method:
Example of how the NSCopying protocol is defined which is defined in the
framework Foundation with the header NSObject.h
@protocol NSCopying
- (id) copyWithZone: (NSZone *) zone;
@end
If you decide to adopt the protocol in a class, you must implement the method called
copyWithZone :. The compiler is informed that a class adopts a protocol
listing the protocol name between angle brackets (<..>) on the line
@interface. An example of how the NSCopying protocol is adopted is:
@interface AddressBook: NSObject <NSCopying>
If you want to adopt more than one protocol, it should be done as follows:
@interface AddressBook: NSObject <NSCopying, NSCoding>
Page 205
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 199
Delegation
Delegation is a simple and useful pattern in which the object of a program acts
in coordination with another object. The delegating object maintains
a reference to another object (the delegate) and at an appropriate time sends it a
message. The message informs the delegate of an event that the delegating object is
find about to run or just run it. Delegate can reply
to the message by updating its appearance or that of other objects in the application, and in
some cases it may return a value that prevents another event from executing. The
The main value of delegation is that it allows you to customize different objects of
easy way into a central object.
Page 206
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 200
TT20110007
Annex B.
Distributed Algorithms
Many distributed algorithms require a process to act as a coordinator,
initiator, or playing a special role. In general, no matter what
process has this special responsibility, but someone has to do it.
If all the processes are exactly the same, with no distinguishing characteristics,
there is no way to select one to be the special one. Consequently,
we will assume that each process has a unique number, for example, its address of
network (for simplicity, we will assume one process per machine). In general, the choice
algorithm attempts to locate the process with the largest number and
designate him as coordinator. Algorithms differ in the way they perform
location.
Furthermore, we will assume that each process knows the number of the other processes.
What the processes don't know is which ones are increasing and which ones are decreasing.
The goal of a choice algorithm is to ensure that when you initiate a choice,
this concludes with all the processes according to which will be the new
coordinator. Among which the bullying algorithm and token-ring are chosen
commonly for its simplicity and speed of development.
Bully algorithm
When any process notices that the coordinator is no longer responding
petitions start an election. A process, P, holds an election of the following
way:
1. P sends a CHOICE message to all processes with numbers
superiors.
2. If no process responds, P wins the election and becomes the
coordinator.
3. If one of the higher processes responds, take command. The work of P
It's done.
At any time, a process can receive a CHOICE message from
some of his colleagues with a smaller number. When such a message arrives, the
Recipient sends an OK message back to the sender to indicate that it is
active and who will take control. The recipient then celebrates uses choice, to
unless you already have one. At some point, all processes give less
one, who is then the new coordinator. He announces his victory by sending a
message to all processes in which it indicates that from that moment it is the
new coordinator.
Page 207
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 201
If a previously failed process is recovered, hold an election. Yes
happens that the process with the largest number is running, he will win the
election and will assume the job of the coordinator. Thus, the biggest boy in the world
people always win, hence the name "abusón algorithm", which is
shown in Figure 200 .
Figure 200. The abuser's algorithm.
(a) Process 4 celebrates the election. (b) Processes 5 and 6 answer,
signaling 4 to stop. (c) Now 5 and 6 hold an election. (of the
process 6 tells 5 to stop. € Process 6 wins, and communicates it to
everybody.
Page 208
IMeAC Prototype Framework
Page 202
TT20110007
Ring algorithms. (Token-ring)
Unlike some ring algorithms, this one does not use a token. We assume
that the processes are physically or logically ordered, in such a way that each
The process knows its successor as shown in Figure 201 . When
any process warns that the coordinator does not work, elaborates a message of
CHOICE that contains your own process number and sends the message to your
successor. If the successor failed, the sender skips it and goes to the next member of the
ring, the next after it, until it locates a running process. On
every step of the way, the sender adds their own process number to the list
of the message to become a candidate to elect as coordinator.
At some point, the message goes back to the process that started it all. This process
acknowledges this event when it receives an incoming message containing its own
process number. At that point, the message type changes to COORDINATOR and
circulates once more, this time to inform everyone that he is the coordinator (the
member of the list with the highest number) and which are the members of the new
ring. When this message has circulated once, it is removed and everyone returns to the
job.
Figure 201. Choice algorithm using a ring
Choices in wireless environments
Traditional choice algorithms are generally based on assumptions
that are not real in wireless environments. For example, they assume that the step of
messages is reliable and that the network topology does not change. These assumptions
are false in most wireless environments, especially those
implemented for custom mobile networks.
Page 209
IMeAC Prototype Framework
TT20110007
Page 203
Only a few protocols have been developed for elections that work on networks
to measure. Vasudevan and colleagues propose a solution that you can handle
failing nodes and partitioned networks. An important property of your solution is
that the best leader can be chosen, rather than randomly, as in the
previous algorithms. Their protocol works as follows. To simplify
our explanation, we will only focus on custom networks, and
we will ignore that the nodes can move taking into account the
algorithms shown in Figure 202 .
Consider a custom wireless network. To elect a leader, any node of
the network, called the source, can initiate an election by sending a
CHOICE to your immediate neighbors (that is, to the nodes of your range). When a
node receives a CHOICE for the first time, designates the sender as its parent, and
then send a CHOICE message to your immediate neighbors, with
exception of the parent. When one node receives a CHOICE message from another
node other than its parent, simply acknowledges received.
When node R has designated node Q as its parent, it forwards the message
of CHOICE to its immediate neighbors (except Q) and awaits the arrival of the
acknowledgments before sending acknowledgment of the CHOICE of Q message.
waiting has an important consequence. First, notice that the neighbors who already
have selected a parent immediately respond to R. More specifically,
if all neighbors already have a parent, R is a leaf node and will be able to respond
quickly to Q. By doing so, it also reports information such as lifetime
stack and other resource capabilities.
This information will later enable Q to compare the capabilities of R with those of
other nodes, and select the best node to be the leader. Of course, Q ha
sent a CHOICE message just because his father, P, has done it too. TO
in turn, when Q at some point acknowledges receipt of the CHOICE message
previously sent by P, it will also pass the most eligible node to P. From this
Thus, the source will have to know at some point which is the best node to
select it as the leader, and then it will transmit this information to the other nodes.

Figure 202. Algorithm of choice in a wireless network, with node a as
source.
(a) Initial network. (b) to (e) Tree construction phase (the last step of
transmission of fei nodes is not shown). (f) The source is reported on
the best node.

such as the graphics card, it is required that the applications that are made for said
device have a pleasant and intuitive visual interface for the user.
